newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta share prices close up but off highs.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta share prices close up but off highs.

text.p: Jakarta share prices ended higher but off highs on Monday on bargain-hunting in some blue-chips combined with active buying of banking stocks, brokers said.
The Jakarta Composite Index closed 4.24 points, or 0.62 percent, higher at 688.05 points after touching an intra-day high of 688.73 points. Gainers led losers by 74 to 44, with 66 counters unchanged.
Blue-chips such as telecommunications firm Telkom cigarette maker Sampoerna and noodle maker Indofood were among the target of bargain-hunters.
Brokers said the market was expected to be firmer on Tuesday as buying interest in firstliners was seen likely to continue.
"Some blue-chips are still at bargain levels. It will attract further buying on Tuesday, I believe," a broker with a foreign firm said.
Shares of banking stocks were active during the day with Bank PDFCI leading rises in the sector, brokers said.

Bank PDFCI was the most active stock with about 9.2 million shares changing hands, rising 400 rupiah to 3,200 rupiah following a report that Bank Indonesia plans to sell its stake in several banks including PDFCI.
Bank Papan Sejahtera and Bank Ficorinvest were active on the same report, brokers said.
Buying interest in other banks such as Bank Negara Indonesia, Bank International Indonesia and Bank Lippo were high on perceptions that their prices were cheap, brokers said.
In contrast to other blue chips, sentiment on cigarette maker Gudang Garam and cement maker Semen Gresik was weak, brokers said.
Gudang Garam closed 325 rupiah lower at 10,325 on a volume of 591,000 shares after a report in the Media Indonesia newspaper that a company official had alledgely stolen 24 billion rupiah.

Semen Gresik fell 75 rupiah to 6,350 rupiah on 689,500 shares. An analyst with a Hong Kong-based brokerage said it was due to recent reports the company had changed its depreciation policy and officials said it might affect 1996 results.
"It sparked selling in Semen Gresik in anticipation of its 1996 net results. Some investors switched their portfolios to other cement stocks," the analyst said.
